Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Grigori Avramidi is "Geometry and Topology of Noncompact Aspherical Manifolds." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Utah, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Mladen Bestvina.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's research during this project focused on the topology of noncompact aspherical manifolds and especially the topology of ends of such manifolds. 


One prominent class of aspherical manifolds are the manifolds of nonpositive curvature. They have been studied from geometric, group theoretic, arithmetic, analytic and dynamical points of view. They are interesting because there are at least two large classes of such manifolds (locally symmetric spaces of noncompact type, the pinched negatively curved manifolds obtained via smooth hyperbolization and branching methods), yet at the same time nonpositive curvature puts strong restrictions on topology. For example, by the Cartan-Hadamard theorem, the universal cover of a nonpositively cureved manifold is contractible so the homotopy type is completely determined by the fundamental group. More deep are various ``rigidity'' results showing that the topology of nonpositively curved manifolds is also determined by their fundamental groups. Such results are valid on the nose for closed manifolds, but in order to get rigidity results for noncompact nonpositivey curved manifolds, one usually has to specify or at least to some extent constrain the topology the end. This is one of the many reasons why understanding the topology of the end is important. For locally symmetric spaces there is a very precise structure theory for ends due, essentially, to Borel and Serre. This theory quickly reduces to understanding ends of arithmetic locally symmetric spaces, which is done in terms of arithmetic data.


In the course of the present research project, the PI (joint with T. Nguyen Phan) developed a structure theory of ends of nonpositively curved manifolds. This structure theory explains some of the topological consequences of the classical Borel-Serre theory of ends of arithmetic manifolds using just the nonpositively curved geometry of the manifolds and not any of the arithmetic structure. It also applies to a much larger class of manifolds than the locally symmetric spaces. Indeed, complementing the structure theory, new examples of nonpositively curved manifolds were constructed with ends whose topology is different from that of locally symmetric and pinched negatively curved manifolds. In the course of this project, new tools (such as Busemann simplices) were developed and a complex was discovered that plays a role for nonpositively curved manifolds analogous to the role played by the rational spherical building for locally symmetric spaces. This should have broader applications in nonpositively curved geometry. 


L2 Betti numbers are analytically defined homotopy invariants of manifolds (and more general spaces). They were initially introduced for closed manifolds by Atiyah in the context of the L2 index theorem. Singer observed (by looking at locally symmetric spaces) that for closed aspherical manifolds these L2 Betti numbers seem to be concentrated in the middle dimension (while the ordinary Betti numbers are not) and the conjecture that this is true for all closed aspherical manifolds is usually called the Singer conjecture. 


During the present project, the PI has studied L2 Betti numbers of aspherical and rationally aspherical manifolds. This included relating L2 Betti numbers to thickening obstructions for manifolds with right-angled Artin fundamntal groups on one hand (joint with M. Davis, B. Okun and K. Schreve), and constructing new rationally aspherical manifolds of lower than expected dimension on the other hand. These rationally aspherical manifolds do not satisfy the conclusion of the Singer conjecture, yet at the same time they are difficult to distinguish from genuine aspherical manifolds using current tools.

 
The PI has studied how much symmetry a given noncompact aspherical manifold can have and found ways to bound the symmetry in terms of the topology of the manifold. Previously, this was well understood for closed aspherical manifolds but not for noncompact ones. In earlier work, the PI had shown how to bound the amount of symmetry for several classes of noncompact manifolds (including locally symmetric spaces and moduil spaces) using special features of the topology of their ends. In the course of the present research, the PI discovered a particular kind of structure on the end of a noncopact aspherical manifold the presence of which allows one bound the amount of symmetry just in terms of the fundamental group. This unifies the earlier results and suggests directions for future research.
